feed.title: Fws' shared items in Google Reader

entry.title: State of the Art in Plant Phenomics: the latest BBSRC research
entry.summary: BBSRC (Biotechnology and Biological Sciences Research Council) news blurb on recent research in plant genetics. The Meg1 gene is expressed only from maternal chromosomes and regulates nutrient provisioning during seed development. This has an effect on seed size and productivity. As such, the research findings are important for global agriculture and food security because it forms a method to improve certain seed traits. More information on the discovery can be found on the BBSRC website.

entry.title: A Dutch company's contribution to the fight against desertification and world hunger
entry.summary: The Groasis Waterboxx developed by the Dutch company AquaPro is a fascinating piece of technology. The Waterbox is a simple device made out of biopolymer that captures water from the air through both rain as well as condensation. The small box is placed around a plant or tree and allows vegetation to grow on dry soil and rocks. The technology has been successfully tested in the Sahara and is now sold through partnership companies across the globe. To find out more about this exciting and innovative anti-desertification technology that has the potential to combat world hunger and improve world food security please visit the Groasis website.

entry.title: Food price dynamics: Where to now? (7 October 2011 01:30-17:30 (GMT+01 (BST)) - Round-table, London)
entry.summary:
Where are prices of cereals headed over the next ten years? And what does this imply for policy?


These questions were addressed at a workshop with presentations from Merritt Cluff of FAO, Dirk Willenbockel from IDS and Chris Gilbert from Trento University. All agreed that prices are likely to fall a little in real terms, but will remain well above the levels seen in the early 2000s.

A panel of specialists chaired by Simon Maxwell, with Brendan Bayley from HMT, Bettina Prato from IFAD, Benoit Daviron from CIRAD, and Ruth Kelly from Oxfam, shared their views on the policy implications of a world facing sustained higher food prices and possible increased volatility.

A report of the event, a blog outlining key messages from discussion, as well as presentations and videos from key speakers can be found on this page.

View full details

entry.title: IWMI Water Issue Brief - 8: Water, poverty and equity
entry.summary: The world's population is set to exceed nine billion by 2050, adding a third more inhabitants to the planet than today. Feeding them, taking into consideration increasing demand for diets based on fruit, vegetables and meat, will require farmers to double food production.

source.title: IWMI Publication - International Water Management Institute

entry.title: Breakthrough in the production of flood-tolerant crops
entry.summary: This week thousands of families lost their homes and crops as flood waters swept across Central America. In Thailand huge tracts of farmland were submerged as the country faced its worst flooding in 50 years. Across the globe agricultural production is at risk as catastrophic flooding becomes a world-wide problem.

entry.title: World Food Day Sunday 16th of October 2011
Published this Monday: The State of World Food Insecurity 2011 by the Food & Agriculture Organization.
entry.summary: FAO published its report on global price volatility and how it affects developing countries this Monday. Please find the full report HERE.

entry.title: Key Publication: Food self-sufficiency and natural hazards in China
entry.summary: In this article Elisabeth Simelton presents a regional analysis of the self-sufficiency of China's agricultural sector. It combines agricultural and disaster data to assess the resilience of the Chinese agricultural system in the face of floods and droughts.

entry.title: Food Assistance Builds Bridge Between Hunger And Hope As Millions Mark World Food Day
entry.summary: Lusaka – The World Food Programme (WFP) today marks World Food Day by highlighting the vital role that food assistance plays during humanitarian crises, supporting recovery in the immediate aftermath of disasters, and building the resilience that is necessary to ensure food security.

entry.title: WFP Welcomes Brazil And Spain Contributions Worth US$6 Million To Provide Food For Vulnerable People In Sudan
entry.summary: KHARTOUM Brazil and Spain have teamed up to make a joint contribution of US$ 6 million towards United Nations World Food Programme (WFP) Emergency Operation in Sudan.

entry.title: World hunger report 2011: High, volatile prices set to continue
entry.summary: Food price volatility featuring high prices is likely to continue and possibly increase, making poor farmers, consumers and countries more vulnerable to poverty and food insecurity, the United Nations' three Rome-based agencies said in the global hunger report published today.

entry.title: We must protect biodiversity while tackling food security, warns researcher
entry.summary: An increasing number of plant species are under threat from the demands being put on agriculture to produce more food to support the growing world population which is increasing by 160,000 every day. In a study published in the Proceedings of the Royal Society today, Dr Jonathan Storkey has brought together data for the first time on the threat status of plants found in arable habitats across Europe and warns of the importance of protecting plant diversity as we focus on increasing food production.
